_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Crowne Cold Storage has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Crowne Cold Storage, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Crowne Cold Storage has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name           | Process Chemical          | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration    Anhydrous Ammonia           17,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP an

d RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



Crowne Cold Storage operates a commercial packing and storage facility for blue berries in Stockton, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system which provides refrigeration capacity to the following:

(8) Post-cool Rooms

(1) Staging Area

(1) Loading Dock

(2) Refrigerated Domes



The Refrigerated Domes are equipped with evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation while Post-cool Rooms, Staging Area, and Loading Dock are equipped with evaporators and a pump recirculator as required for pumped overfeed operation. The refrigeration machinery is contained within the Machinery Room and outside the Post-cool Room. A partial list of system components includes:

(1) High Pressure Receiver

(1) Main Suction Accumulator

(1) Liquid Transfer Vessel

(1) Liquid Recirculator; equipped with an Oil Pot and (2) Ammonia Pumps

(2) FES Screw Compressors

(1) Imeco Evaporative Condenser

(19) Ceiling Suspended Evaporators



The Refrigerated Domes operate as follows: high pressure liquid from a high pressure receiver is piped to each dome, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator. From the accumulators, cold liquid ammonia is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulators. The ammonia vapor is returned from the accumulators through a suction return line to a main suction accumulator. From there, it passes through the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a wa

ter cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.



The Post-cool Rooms, Staging Area, and Loading Dock operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receivers is piped through a liquid feed solenoid valve, an expansion valve, and into the liquid recirculator. From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each evaporator, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into evaporator.  Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator.  As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the liquid recirculators. The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the recirculator and the gas is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.



Crowne Cold Storage was purchased from Calamco in 2014. California Controlled Atmsophere was hired in 2015 to supply and install new refrigeration equipment for a new Machinery Room. In addition, California Controlled Atmosphere disconnected the tunnel piping from Calamco's system and moved two (2) screw compressors to the Machinery Room.

The refrigeration system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent ammonia gas to a diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. Each entrance to a machinery room contains emergency refrigeration shutdown and ventilation controls for use during an emergency situation.



The ammonia system at Crowne Cold Storage consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are

interconnected by piping. As such, Crowne Cold Storage has one (1) refrigeration process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Crowne Cold Storage has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Crowne Cold Storage facility is an integral part of the overall business. The process is only operational approximately 3 months out of the year. The remainder of the year, ammonia is stored in vessels. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Crowne Cold Storage has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Crowne Cold Storage's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupation

al Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Crowne Cold Storage has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Crowne Cold Storage continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Crowne Cold Storage's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Crowne Cold Storage's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Crowne Cold Storage has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compli

ance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Crowne Cold Storage has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Crowne Cold Storage now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Crowne Cold Storage employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Crowne Cold Storage will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
